evidence.text: In 1971, President Nixon issued an Executive Order granting collective bargaining rights to members of the Foreign Service because “the effective participation by the men and women of the Foreign Service in the formation of personnel policies and procedures affecting the conditions of their employment is essential to the efficient administration of the Foreign Service.”
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: 1971 Executive Order by Nixon granting collective bargaining rights to Foreign Service members, citing essential participation in personnel policy formation for efficient administration

evidence.text: In 1978, Congress enacted Chapter 71 of the Civil Service Reform Act, also known as the Federal Service Labor-Management Relations Statute to guarantee those rights in law. But, because Congress found that “the unique conditions of Foreign Service employment require a distinct framework for the development and implementation of modern, constructive, and cooperative relationships between management officials and organizations representing members of the Service,” in 1980 it enacted the Foreign Service Labor-Management Relations Statute, 22 U.S.C. §§ 4101-4140, which is Chapter 10 of Title I of the Foreign Service Act of 1980.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: 1980 enactment of Foreign Service Labor-Management Relations Statute (FSLMRS) establishing distinct labor framework for Foreign Service employment

evidence.text: On March 27, 2025, Defendant Trump issued Executive Order No. 14,251, Exclusions from Federal Labor-Management Programs, 90 Fed. Reg. 14553 (Mar. 27, 2025), which invoked § 4103(b) and terminated the collective bargaining rights of all the Foreign Service members employed by the Department of State and USAID.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: March 27, 2025 Executive Order No. 14,251 by Trump excluding Department of State and USAID from FSLMRS, terminating collective bargaining rights of Foreign Service members

evidence.text: The White House issued a “fact sheet” simultaneously with the Executive Order in which it candidly admitted that the President’s Executive Order was issued to curtail the power of and to punish those particular labor organizations who, like AFSA, have ostensibly “obstructed” the President’s efforts to illegally dismantle the Federal government and to illegally dismiss large segments of the Federal workforce these labor organizations represent: President Trump is taking action to ensure that agencies vital to national security can execute their missions without delay and protect the American people. Certain Federal unions have declared war on President Trump’s agenda. ... The largest Federal union describes itself as “fighting back” against Trump. It is widely filing grievances to block Trump policies.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: White House fact sheet admitting Executive Order was issued to retaliate against unions like AFSA for opposing Trump's agenda
